title: Newtons second law - tension in string

content.description: Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>A</mtext></math> of mass <math alttext="2 m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>B</mtext></math> of mass <math alttext="m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> are on a horizontal surface and are attached by a string with negligible mass. Another string with negligible mass, which is attached to Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, passes over a pulley with negligible mass and connects to a hanging block of mass <math alttext="2 m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is initially held at rest before being released. Frictional forces are negligible.
content.question: When the system is released from rest, the tension in the string connecting blocks <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> is <math alttext="T sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. The positions of blocks <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> are now switched, and the system is again released from rest. The tension in the string connecting blocks <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> after their positions are switched is <math alttext="T sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Is <math alttext="T sub 1 equals T sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> ? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the acceleration of the three-block system will be the same as in the original setup.
Yes, because the net external force acting on the three-block system is the same as in the original setup.
No, because the force of tension in the string accelerates a less massive block than in the original setup.
No, because the acceleration of the system will be larger than in the original setup when the more massive block is moved closer to the pulley.

content.answer: No, because the force of tension in the string accelerates a less massive block than in the original setup.
